review_blob: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a hazy gold. Smells strongly of yeast and spice. Taste is a burst full of flavor (at first earthy, malty, and yeasty with a hint of vanilla) that gradually ripens into strong spice and alcohol. Finish is very boozy.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a beautiful, deep red. Taste is a powerful punch of delicious cherries. A nice mix of tart and sweet. Crisp and never cloying. Some grain, light spice, and yeast from the saison also comes through nicely so that the cherries arent quite overpowering. Despite the powerful flavor, the body is surprisingly light, more reminiscent of champagne than beer.
beer_name: Insight Doe Eyes Saison & Door County Cherries

review_blob: Growler from the brewery. Pours pitch black with a light tan head. Smells of roasted chocolate, coffee, toffee, and vanilla with a toasted malt and slight wood background. Taste is briefly and immediately a leap of light, fresh, and crisp hops that is slowly, but with acceleration, engulfed by descent into a dark, sticky, and alcoholic black hole. The initial light character gradually dissolves into dark notes of chocolate, coffee, toffee, and vanilla, which endures in the finish. A very well crafted beer.

Growler from the brewery. Pours a nice light gold. Smell is a balance mix of crisp hops and citrus fruit, presumably yuzu. Taste starts with a brief wave of yuzu, which quickly subsides into a background of refreshing hops and light malt. Finish is bitter. Very crisp and refreshing. The yuzu adds an interesting twist to a classic pale ale. Works well.
beer_name: Insight The Garden Of The Hell Chicken Pale Ale - Chapter XXXIII

review_blob: Growler from the brewery. Very drinkable beer. Compares well to British bitters like Fullers London Pride. Smell is light--a little bit of malt. Taste is a pleasant blend of toffee, malt, and light British hops. Body is light but still substantive. Good beer for the style. Would recommend to anyone looking for a more sessionable beer.
beer_name: Insight Return Of The Lambton Dragon Session Ale - Chapter XXXIX

review_blob: Growler from brewery. Pours a light hazy gold with a light head. Very aromatic--smell is a blend of fruit, light spice, and yeast. Taste is light on the tongue--notes of spice and light fruit weave through a background of soft malt and light wine/booze. Palate is very light and accented by gentle, champagne-like carbonation. Finish is light with whispers of spice and alcohol. Very enjoyable. A really good beer.
beer_name: Insight In The Halls of the Sunken City Saison - Chapter VII

review_blob: Growler from the brewery. Pours a deep gold color with a light head. Nice smell of fresh citrus, hops, and pine. Very crisp. Taste starts off crisp too--strong bitter hops balanced with citrus--with fine carbonation before developing deeper tones of citrus resin and malt and a thicker palate. Very balanced and smooth. Finish is pleasant--not too bitter--and a little sticky. Great all around. Packs a lot of flavor within a surprisingly smooth and dynamic body.
beer_name: Insight An Obstruction On The Troll Way Citrus IPA - Chapter XXIX

review_blob: 12 oz. can. Pours a slightly hazy pear golden color with a frothy head. Smells of yeast and spice - solid but not too eventful. Taste is a bit better - a smooth blend of yeast, coriander, and clove. Very drinkable and refreshing. Probably not the best Belgian white, but it is solid.

33cL bottle in Belgium. Pours dark brown molasses. Smells strongly of butter toffee with yeast, brown sugar, and a hint of nut. Flavor is a strong mix of alcohol, toffee, fresh creamy butter, molasses, brown sugar, nut, and yeast with some spice too. Very light and fuzzy/bubbly. But not as light or smooth as other quads (e.g., Westvleteren or De Konigshoeven). As expected though, its still very good.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark brown. Smells of sweet roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate. Taste is a smooth balance of chocolate, coffee, caramel, toffee, roasted malt, and lightly bitter hops. Very good balance of flavors, but the taste is somewhat static -- it would be more interesting if the flavors and balance were more dynamic. Still a good beer that is delightful and smooth.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark coffee brown with a persistent dark hazelnut brown head. Nice aroma. Smells of brown sugar, dark fruit (cherry), and roasted caramel malt -- complex, though not as complex as some other imperial stouts. Taste starts out rich, sweet, and malty with lots of roasted and toasted malts, toffee, vanilla, chocolate, and coffee flavors. Toward the middle, the taste begins to turn bitter with an increasing hint of dark fruit. Finishes on a balanced note. Aftertaste is malty. Palate doesnt have the engine oil thickness that some similar imperial stouts manage. Overall, a very good and enjoyable beer. Not the best in its class, but it is solid.
beer_name: Samuel Adams LongShot Five Crown Imperial Stout

review_blob: 16 oz. can. Pours a dark amber brown with a foamy tan head. Smells of light hops, caramel malt, earthy notes, and a hint of vanilla. Tastes is a subtle blend of vanilla, toffee, molasses, earthy notes, coffee, and hops. Pretty nice balance throughout, although the hops come out more predominantly at toward the end. Finish is smooth but a little bitter.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a wheat yellow color with a bubbly head. Smell is a nice blend of strong hops, citrus grapefruit, and pine. Taste is initially very tart and bitter. The bitterness then lightens up with the addition of malt flavors. This is followed by a wave of citrus, after which there is a recapitulation to the hoppy bitterness in the finish. Flavor is very fresh. True to the style and a refreshing beer.

12 oz. bottle. Pours an amber caramel brown with a foamy tan head. Smells of caramel malt and earthly hops with notes of fruit. Tastes of strong caramel malt with an underlying hop bitterness and alcohol flavor. The flavor balance slowly disappears by the end of the beer with the bitter and alcohol flavors dominating. It still tastes good, but its not perfect. Full bodied and sticky; a little heavy and dry in the finish.
beer_name: Samuel Adams LongShot Derfs Secret Alt

review_blob: 12 oz. bottle. Smells of dark roasted malt with hints of caramel and dark fruit. Tastes of thickly roasted malt, molasses, brown sugar, and barley with a hint of dark fruity esters. Thick body and fairly smooth -- though not perfectly. Fairly good.
beer_name: Samuel Adams LongShot A Dark Night in Munich

review_blob: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a nice amber wheat color. Head is a bit thin. Smells of grains and grassy hops with a very slight citrus character. Taste is a nice balance of malt and grain against bitter hop/orange citrus.  Goes down smoothly with a medium body.
12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark brown nut caramel color. Smells of nut, toffee, vanilla, caramel, and butter. Taste is a strong caramel with hints of coffee, hops, nut, and vanilla. Nice.

12 oz. bottle. Pours an apricot caramel color. Smells of fruit, raisin, grape, apricot, and fruity esters. Tastes of crisp honey and grape against a balanced fruit malt background (background is less crisp). Fine carbonation accents its light and smooth feeling. A fine and interesting beer.
beer_name: Dogfish Head Midas Touch Golden Elixir

review_blob: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark brown with a cream head. Smells of roasted coffee and chocolate malt. Taste is of crips coffee roast with balanced bitterness and caramel/toffee malt with a roasted finish and aftertaste. Palate is nice -- not overly creamy but sufficiently thick -- feels relatively clean. An enjoyable stout.

750mL bottle. Pours a dark amber brown with a large tan head. Smells of wood, vanilla, scotch, oak, caramel, and chocolate. Flavor is a subtle mixture of smells -- predominantly dark chocolate, oak wood, earthy notes, and a hint of whiskey. There is also a note of caramel malt in the background, which comes out as a large part of the finish, and passing notes of smoke and dryness. Always smooth and never overbearing; very subtle -- not in your face at all. Palate is smooth, medium thick, but not overly potent. Great balance. Very smooth. A very good beer.
12 oz. bottle. Aroma is a potent wheat smell -- smooth with a bit of malt and caramel. Taste is of balanced spice, clove, wheat, malt, and alcohol. A nice mix, but not very dynamic.

12 oz. bottle. Smooth, not too sweet. Raspberry dominates the character and, although its admittedly balanced with respect to the wheat, it leaves little room for more complex flavors to emerge. Still, its interesting for its incredibly smooth palate alone.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a caramel brown. Smells of toasted malt, bread, and nut. Taste also contains notes of toasted malt, bread, and nut along with elements of chocolate. Pretty well balanced, but perhaps a little too toasted. Palate is relatively creamy but not overly so. Pretty nice, but not exceptional.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a golden tan. Smell isnt particularly strong -- some crisp hops and citrus. Flavor is adequately strong, however. Taste is initially of crisp hops (though not the typical American IPA hops), resin, and subtle spice with a slight smooth malt background. Additional layers of citrus emerge in the middle, followed by a malt layer leading into a slightly boozy dry hop-resin finish. Palate is slightly sticky, but the flavors are very smooth. Its an interesting and fairly good beer.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a light brown caramel. Smells a bit sweet -- light caramel malt, not a lot of hops. Taste is a bit plain -- some light English hops over a predominant biscuit malt. Smooth and well-balanced though. Not overly exciting, but its ok -- and certainly drinkable.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy yellow-gold with a frothy white head. Aroma is of yeast, floral/herbal notes, and spice. Taste is initially yeasty with some veiled coriander, clove, and pepper followed by a crescendo of spice, which mellows out after a climax. The remainder of the beer brings out veiled notes of honey and toffee toward the finish, which is subtle and lasting. Very smooth and balanced. A great tripel.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a deep gold color with a persistent head. Smells strongly of crisp citrus hops with some pine resin. As expected, the taste is dominated by a heavy hop bitterness with some elements of citrus and pine. A classic sort of IPA -- crisply bitter but not harshly so. Nice.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a deep brown amber with a foamy cream head. Smells of toasted malt and toffee. Tastes of nut, toffee, and molasses with a background of malt and bread. Palate seems about right -- dry and smooth (almost smoky) with a medium-to-light thickness. Pretty nice and very drinkable.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a light gold-yellow with a fizzy white head. Smells strongly of yeast and spice with some floral notes. Taste is a mix of spice, hops, and yeast notes with a bready background. The flavor is initially lively but dulls to a somewhat unexciting and shallow finish with a slight, but unappetizing, hint of metallic tartness. Definitely not the best of its style.

12 oz. bottle. Pours an amber-orange with a lasting head. Smells of sharp hops and citrus. Taste starts as a fairly standard hops and citrus combination (with a notable crispness), then develops a side of lightly toasted malt. Pretty good balance throughout. Overall, a very decent and drinkable pale ale.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a nice clear yellow gold with an ephemeral head. Aroma contains a lot of apricot (not quite overpowering, but close) with some blander notes of wheat in the background. Taste is overpowered by sweetness, apricot and a note of elder flower. It is hard to detect other flavors, but there is some wheat, light malt, and maybe a little honey. Medium palate -- not very light/thin due, it seems, largely to the apricot essence. Could be a bit more effervescent. Overall, doesnt taste acrid or anything, but it could certainly use a better balance scheme.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a deep amber with an effervescent cream head. Smell is very light -- gives the impression of being lithe and fizzy. There is a light sense of yeast and brown sugar and, interestingly (in that it is soft), a soft character of dark fruit (date and fig). There is considerable, but very fine and soft, carbonation that pierces the otherwise dense palate. The taste starts with bland notes of nut, wood, and malt, but soon develops notes of date, fig, plum, and a sprinkling of brown sugar. The remainder of the beer is characterized by a substantial crescendo in alcohol and spice intensity, resulting in a climax of clarity (as if peeling away the palate thickness and disintegrating the spice flavor) and balanced flavor in the finish, which is notably a bit a heavy. The balance here is between malt, fruit, and yeast with a slight bitter touch. Makes me think of piercing the veil of the maya (c.f. Percy Bysshe Shelleys "Lift not the painted veil which those who live / call life"), but its, sadly, far from that epiphanic. Still, it is reasonably good.
beer_name: Boulevard Smokestack Series - The Sixth Glass Quadrupel

review_blob: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a light pear gold. Smells of light malt and barley and mild hops. Taste is a fine mixture of light maltiness, honey, and mild bitterness -- a balanced light flavor. Smooth with a refreshing carbonation and a substantial body. A good pilsner.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a cherry caramel color. Smell is a light and wafting mixture of light yeast, complex fruit (elements of fig, grape, and cherry), and sweet honey and caramel. Notable for its complete lack of banana character. Flavor is a rich, complex layering of fruit, sweet sugars, and hints of candied licorice and chocolate with weaving traces of yeast notes. There is initially a caramel honey malt base, which is followed by gradual injections of fruit notes before arriving at the fruity belly full of deep fig, date, and cherry. This follows through into a rich finish with hints of assorted sweets -- candied fruit, toffee, chocolate, and licorice. Palate is thick and moderately sticky with a brisk champagne-like initial carbonation. An exceptional brew.

12 oz. can. Pours a dark amber brown. Smell is is very fresh -- strong hops, citrus, resin, and a pervasive toasted malt. Taste is initially a crisp hop and citrus, which proceeds to see-saw in and out of a dark toasted malt, volleying flavors from side to side before settling in to a thick-set balance between bitter and dark. Palate is smooth and medium thick. An interesting and somewhat playful brew.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a caramel amber brown with a short foamy cream head. Smells of subtle fresh hops, caramel, and nut with some very slight roasted malt. Tastes is a fine balance between an earthy hop crispness and a malt flavor backed with nut, toffee, bread, a hint of molasses, and a tad bit of smoke. Very nicely balanced and clean -- a nice session beer.
beer_name: Sierra Nevada Tumbler Autumn Brown Ale

review_blob: 16 oz. can. Pours a nice caramel amber. Smells strongly of grapefruit and citrus hop with a hint of sweet malt. Taste comes in asynchronous waves of deep citrus hop bitter and sweet caramel malt -- a nice dynamic balance throughout though. Palate is thick enough to add substance but not too thick to remove the hoppy crispness that the flavor portrays so well. A very nice IPA.

75cL bottle. Pours a clear butterscotch gold. Smells of honey and wheat malt. Tastes of wheat and caramel malt with honey, alcohol, and a bit of spice. Finish is spicy and alcoholic. Pretty nice. Interesting taste and pretty good balance -- not too sweet.
UPDATED: AUG 13, 2011

12 oz. bottle. Pours a light gold with a white head. Smells of strong citrus and hops with a very light floral note -- the aroma feels very light in temperament. Tastes initially very crisp and citrusy before blooming into hoppy bitterness. This is followed by a wave of malt and floral characters, which subsides into the hoppy finish. Despite the name, there is exceptional balance throughout between hops and malt. I like the domination of citrus over floral characters in the smell and early flavors -- really gives a light, crisp feel at the onset. Doesnt come close to the extreme on hops; rather, it achieves a very nice soft and smooth hop character, which still retains some punch. What it does, it does very well.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep coffee black with tan head. Smell feels light but is of heavy coffee, chocolate, barley malt, slight fruit, and slight yeast. Feels thick and is potent in flavor and dynamics. Taste is initially sweet and fruity with a bit of brown sugar and nut. Then, it gradually descends into a black chocolate and coffee flavor becoming darker, thicker, and more bitter over time (a descent into pitch black). It then ripens into a thick deep roasted coffee bitter with a touch of caramel and smooth liquorice cream. The finish is long, dark, and thick -- completely covers the palate for some time. Extraordinary in that it gives a great sense of balance to a complete range of dynamics -- and subtlety and complexity to a single dynamic trend -- it gives a moment of "dont think, but [taste]". Very robust, very interesting, and very good.
beer_name: North Coast Old Rasputin Russian Imperial Stout

review_blob: 12 oz. bottle. Pours an amber caramel with a creamy head. Smells bready with some toffee and caramel malt and dull hops. Tastes of bread and toffee malt with a formidable hop background and later takes on a slight fruity note -- almost like a touch of marmalade, which sweetens the background flavors and ebbs into the dry bitter finish. Palate is very clean. Drinkable and interesting. Very nice.

12 oz. can. Pours a hazy maple brown. Smells of fig, brown sugar, vanilla, oak, and slight cinnamon -- a nice blend. Taste is initially of fig, yeast, and brown sugar (with a slight banana character)  followed by a lacing of vanilla and oak. This precedes a strong wave of spice-infused alcohol (cinnamon and clove), which ebbs into a complex finish with the resurgence of a vanilla and cinnamon lacing. Palate is refreshingly light, smooth, and creamy -- the beer is not weighed down considerably by the vivid flavors or the alcohol; however, it doesnt really achieve the extremely light and crisp feeling found in the best Belgian beers (c.f. Westvleteren or Westmalle). Also, its balance is slightly skewed toward the sweet spicy cinnamon notes. Still, its an enjoyably flavorful beer even if its not the best Belgian style ale brewed.

12 oz. can. Pours a clear gold with a frothy white head. Smells of cascade hops, citrusy grapefruit, and pine (I would say the aroma could be a bit stronger though). Taste is initially of pine and citrus flavors, shortly after which distinct lemon and grapefruit tones emerge, which later develop into a hoppy citrus character. There is then a slight kick of malt before the dive into the bitter hoppy finish. Palate is smooth and creamy leading into the dry finish. Very hoppy and crisp but surprisingly smooth and subtle with a good balance of flavors. Definitely a great example of a classic American IPA, as the name would suggest.
beer_name: 21st Amendment Brew Free or Die IPA

review_blob: 12 oz. bottle. Pours a deep dark brown with a foamy tan-cream head. Smells of chocolate malt and perhaps a hint of coffee -- a very modest aroma; could be a bit stronger. Taste is initially of bitter dark chocolate and barley flavors. Richness crescendos very quickly followed by a more gradual increase in sweetness and creaminess (all follow through right into the finish). A slight roasted note also comes in to play in the last third. Finish is sweet with a slight resurgence of bitter and barley notes. Palate is initially crisp and later very creamy in line with the taste. Very good -- only somewhat lacking in the intensity of the aroma.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark caramel-amber brown with a quickly disappearing head. Smell is weak in strength, but there is a slight whiff of malt and molasses. Taste comes in stages: initially a woody caramel malt followed by the addition of of molasses and subsequent crescendo of brown sugar, and finally a hint of nut and fruit (maybe a bit of apricot) all the way into the finish. Finish is dry with a resurgence of caramel and nut and a side of bitter. Feels rich and thick without being syrupy. Very well balanced and quite good. My chief complaint is regarding the weak aroma. The flavors could also be a bit more vivid, but that would likely sacrifice drinkability, so perhaps thats best left for a barleywine.
beer_name: Big Sky Moose Drool Brown Ale

review_blob: 12 oz. bottle. Pours an orange gold with a foamy white head. Smell is of hops and citrus with a floral background. Flavor is a crisp citrus at the onset with a subtle floral note, which blossoms into an edge of sweet elder flower. The flavor changes to a stringent hoppy bitter just before the finish. Finishes dry. Medium body with a thick mouthfeel, which seems to somehow detract from the crisp feeling in the finish -- i.e., the finish is a bit muddled. Otherwise, a very decent ale.

12 oz. bottle. Pours very dark with a frothy brown head. Pretty aromatic -- smells of coffee, chocolate, and roasted malt. Taste is a wave of roasted flavors against a solid background of coffee, chocolate, caramel, and crisp hops. Feels thick, creamy (with slight crisp carbonation), and full bodied. Very nice.

75cL bottle. Pours a dark caramel-amber brown with a foamy tan head and tree branch lacing. Smells of spice (clove), brown sugar, yeast, and alcohol. Full bodied with a boozy feeling into the finish. Tastes of dark caramel, clove, toffee, and yeast with a hint at banana and some dark fruits. Feels heavy and syrupy. Finish is a thick brown sugar and caramel with a kick of bitterness. Pretty well-balanced throughout (there are perhaps a few times when the spice overshadows the other flavors, but nothing too serious). Definitely a good beer, but it doesnt have the light and lithe feeling that some (relatively heavy) Belgian beers have.

Pint from cask at Far from the Madding Crowd in Oxford. Pours a deep amber caramel brown -- very nice. Smells of buttery and roasted nut, tea, and yeast (the yeast smell was a little unexpected). Taste is initially a malty complex with a striking note of coffee and roast. The dark note is later absorbed into the main body of flavor while releasing notes of butter, nut, citrus, and hops. At the least, an interesting show of flavors. Finish is dry and a tad peppery. An enjoyable pub drink -- not the epitome of beer, but it is at least interesting.
